hints_html: For evaluating the integral, change the order of integration.
hints_latex: For evaluating the integral, change the order of integration.
hints_raw: For evaluating the integral, change the order of integration.
question: 5 (a)
sols_html:
(i)

(ii) Since \(\displaystyle \cos(x^3)\) is hard to integrate with respect to \(\displaystyle x\), we change the order of integration. Using the sketch of (i) and that \(\displaystyle x=\sqrt{-y}\) is equivalent to \(\displaystyle y = -x^2\) (and \(\displaystyle x\geq 0\)) we find that

\[\begin{aligned} \int_{-4}^0\int_{\sqrt{-y}}^2\cos(x^3)\;\text{d}x\text{d}y &= \int_0^2\int_{-x^2}^0 \cos(x^3)\;\text{d}y\text{d}x\\ &= \int_0^2\cos(x^3)[y]_{-x^2}^0\;\text{d}x\\ &= \int_0^2\cos(x^3)x^2\;\text{d}x\\ &= [\frac13\sin(x^3)]_0^2 = \frac13\sin(8) - \frac13\sin(0) \\ &= \frac13\sin(8)\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
(i) \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH200/December_2011/Math200Dec11Q5a.png}

(ii) Since $\displaystyle \cos(x^3)$ is hard to integrate with respect
to $\displaystyle x$, we change the order of integration. Using the
sketch of (i) and that $\displaystyle x=\sqrt{-y}$ is equivalent to
$\displaystyle y = -x^2$ (and $\displaystyle x\geq 0$) we find that

\begin{align*}
\int_{-4}^0\int_{\sqrt{-y}}^2\cos(x^3)\;\text{d}x\text{d}y &= \int_0^2\int_{-x^2}^0 \cos(x^3)\;\text{d}y\text{d}x\\
&= \int_0^2\cos(x^3)[y]_{-x^2}^0\;\text{d}x\\
&= \int_0^2\cos(x^3)x^2\;\text{d}x\\
&= [\frac13\sin(x^3)]_0^2 = \frac13\sin(8) - \frac13\sin(0) \\
&= \frac13\sin(8)
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
(i) 
[[File:Math200Dec11Q5a.png|300px|Region of integration]]

(ii)
Since <math>\displaystyle \cos(x^3) </math> is hard to integrate with respect to <math>\displaystyle x </math>, we change the order of integration. 
Using the sketch of (i) and that <math>\displaystyle x=\sqrt{-y} </math> is equivalent to <math>\displaystyle y = -x^2 </math> (and <math>\displaystyle x\geq 0</math>) we find that


<math>\displaystyle \begin{align}
 \int_{-4}^0\int_{\sqrt{-y}}^2\cos(x^3)\;\text{d}x\text{d}y &= \int_0^2\int_{-x^2}^0 \cos(x^3)\;\text{d}y\text{d}x\\
&= \int_0^2\cos(x^3)[y]_{-x^2}^0\;\text{d}x\\
&= \int_0^2\cos(x^3)x^2\;\text{d}x\\
&= [\frac13\sin(x^3)]_0^2 = \frac13\sin(8) - \frac13\sin(0) \\
&= \frac13\sin(8)
\end{align} </math>
statement_html:
Consider the iterated integral \(\int_{-4}^{0}\int_{\sqrt{-y}}^{2}\cos(x^{3})\,dx\,dy.\)

i) Draw the region of integration.

ii) Evaluate the integral.

Consider the iterated integral
$\int_{-4}^{0}\int_{\sqrt{-y}}^{2}\cos(x^{3})\,dx\,dy.$

i) Draw the region of integration.

ii) Evaluate the integral.
statement_raw:
Consider the iterated integral <math>
\int_{-4}^{0}\int_{\sqrt{-y}}^{2}\cos(x^{3})\,dx\,dy.
</math>

i) Draw the region of integration.

ii) Evaluate the integral.
